If adopted, the new proposal, which is a development of the
so-called "Craven plan,” would permit applications to construct
new television stations on any channel anywhere (excepting
educationally reserved channels, or those within 2f>0 miles of
Canada and Mexico), provided the proposed transmitter locations
met the minimum separation rules, and some other technical
requirements.
This proposal was the principal item on the agenda of the
JCET meeting on May 22* I also reviewed it on the following day
with Leonard ??arks* We are all in agreement that, despite the
continuance of the educations3. reservations, the deletion of the
assignments tabic would be to our disadvantage, since it would
tend to jeopardize the reservations. There would be less to
"hack away at,” than would be the case if the entire allocations
table remained* Furthermore, station separation requirements
would probably be lowered as more and more VHF drop-ins were
arranged*
I agree entirely, therefore, with tine unanimous opinion of
the JCET and also with Lennie Mark’s recommendation, that we oppose
the proposal* Therefore, I suggest that we have Leonard file
